summary:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about AirTag in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The main topic is AirTag, a French startup acquired by Morpho in 2015. They were involved in mobile shopping and payments. The history section mentions their founding in 2006, funding rounds, and key products like their NFC SDKs. They worked with big companies like Reebok, McDonald's, Carrefour, and KFC. There's also a mention of their growth and eventual dissolution in 2018. The criticism part points out that they weren't the first with an NFC SDK, as others had existing ones.

So the key points are: AirTag's role in mobile payments, their NFC technology, partnerships with major brands, growth and funding, and their dissolution. Also, the criticism about their SDK claims. I need to condense this into a concise summary, making sure to highlight the main topic, key concepts like NFC, partnerships, and the outcome of the company. Avoid minor details like specific dates unless they're crucial. Check for the main company's purpose, achievements, and end.
</think>

AirTag was a French startup founded in 2006 that specialized in mobile shopping and payments, pioneering NFC (near-field communication) technology through software development kits (SDKs) and partnerships with major brands like McDonald's, Carrefour, and KFC. The company developed innovative solutions such as loyalty point systems, smartphone-based payments, and mobile wallets, positioning itself as a leader in early mobile commerce. Despite growth and notable collaborations, AirTag faced criticism for overstating its technological firsts, as pre-existing NFC SDKs existed prior to its 2008 launch. The company was acquired by Morpho (a Safran subsidiary) in 2015 but was later dissolved in 2018 without liquidation. Its legacy lies in advancing NFC integration in retail and mobile payments during the early 2010s.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] AirTag (company)


# AirTag (company)



**AirTag** was a French startup that was acquired by Morpho, at the time a Safran subsidiary, in 2015. [S2] It was a mobile shopping and payments provider. [S3] ## History

AirTag was founded in 2006 by Jérémie Leroyer, Cyrille Porteret, Cedric Nicolas and Gunnar Graef. [S4] As of late 2012, investors had provided €6 million in seed capital, following a second-round in 2011 when it secured €4 million. [S5] In October 2008, AirTag launched what it called the first NFC software development kit (SDK). [S6] It included an NFC reader and four types of NFC tags. [S7] In 2012, the company launched another SDK. [S8] This one included hardware for smartphone-based payments. [S9] In 2009, AirTag and its partner Netsize launched *Airtag Pad*, an in-store terminal for clients to check their loyalty points, ask about tailored products, etc. [S10] Reebok hired it for its line of *Go Sport* stores. [S11] Nokia C7, the world's first smartphone with an NFC chip, was able to pick up loyalty points and discount coupons on the phone, through a partnership with AirTag. [S12] AirTag built McDonald's France smartphone app *GoMcDo* which was one of the first to integrate with Apple's Passbook soon after the latter's initial launch with iOS 6 in 2012. [S13] In 2012, Carrefour's mobile app for near-field communication (NFC) purchasing was built by AirTag. [S14] In 2013, French newspaper *L'Express* ranked AirTag among the top 30 French internet startups. [S15] That same spring, AirTag launched KFC’s first mobile wallet to order and pay via smartphone; three months later, 90% of those installing the app were placing orders through it. [S16] Late that year, AirTag admitted it was not profitable. [S17] In 2014, the company had 50 employees when it launched mobile commerce applications for Dia France and for Brioche Dorée. [S18] On November 28, 2018, the sole shareholder IDEMIA Identity et Security France (Courvevoie) decided to dissolve Airtag early without liquidation. [S19] ## Criticism

Whereas AirTag said it launched the first NFC SDK in late 2008, industry magazine *RFID Update* said at the time that there were pre-existing SDK's from Nokia and from Alvin Systems.

I should verify if there's any other mention of the acquisition year elsewhere. Scanning through the rest of the context, there's a sentence S2 that talks about the acquisition, but it's part of the same paragraph as S1. The other sentences mention events in 2006, 2008, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2018, but none of those are related to the acquisition. The key sentence is S1, which clearly states 2015. 

So the answer should be 2015, cited from S1. I need to make sure there are no other citations. The user's format requires each statement to have its citations. Since the answer is in S1, the citation is [S1]. I'll structure the response accordingly.

# AirTag (company)



**AirTag** was a French startup that was acquired by Morpho, at the time a Safran subsidiary, in 2015. [S2] It was a mobile shopping and payments provider. [S3] ## History

AirTag was founded in 2006 by Jérémie Leroyer, Cyrille Porteret, Cedric Nicolas and Gunnar Graef. [S4] As of late 2012, investors had provided €6 million in seed capital, following a second-round in 2011 when it secured €4 million. [S5] In October 2008, AirTag launched what it called the first NFC software development kit (SDK). [S6] It included an NFC reader and four types of NFC tags. [S7] In 2012, the company launched another SDK. [S8] This one included hardware for smartphone-based payments. [S9] In 2009, AirTag and its partner Netsize launched *Airtag Pad*, an in-store terminal for clients to check their loyalty points, ask about tailored products, etc. [S10] Reebok hired it for its line of *Go Sport* stores. [S11] Nokia C7, the world's first smartphone with an NFC chip, was able to pick up loyalty points and discount coupons on the phone, through a partnership with AirTag. [S16] Late that year, AirTag admitted it was not profitable. [S17] In 2014, the company had 50 employees when it launched mobile commerce applications for Dia France and for Brioche Dorée. [S18] On November 28, 2018, the sole shareholder IDEMIA Identity et Security France (Courvevoie) decided to dissolve Airtag early without liquidation. [S19] ## Criticism

[S11] Nokia C7, the world's first smartphone with an NFC chip, was able to pick up loyalty points and discount coupons on the phone, through a partnership with AirTag. [S12] AirTag built McDonald's France smartphone app *GoMcDo* which was one of the first to integrate with Apple's Passbook soon after the latter's initial launch with iOS 6 in 2012. [S13] In 2012, Carrefour's mobile app for near-field communication (NFC) purchasing was built by AirTag. [S14] In 2013, French newspaper *L'Express* ranked AirTag among the top 30 French internet startups. [S15] That same spring, AirTag launched KFC’s first mobile wallet to order and pay via smartphone; three months later, 90% of those installing the app were placing orders through it. [S16] Late that year, AirTag admitted it was not profitable. [S17] In 2014, the company had 50 employees when it launched mobile commerce applications for Dia France and for Brioche Dorée. [S18] On November 28, 2018, the sole shareholder IDEMIA Identity et Security France (Courvevoie) decided to dissolve Airtag early without liquidation. [S19] ## Criticism

Whereas AirTag said it launched the first NFC SDK in late 2008, industry magazine *RFID Update* said at the time that there were pre-existing SDK's from Nokia and from Alvin Systems.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] AirTag (company)


# AirTag (company)



**AirTag** was a French startup that was acquired by Morpho, at the time a Safran subsidiary, in 2015. [S2] It was a mobile shopping and payments provider. [S3] ## History

AirTag was founded in 2006 by Jérémie Leroyer, Cyrille Porteret, Cedric Nicolas and Gunnar Graef. [S4] As of late 2012, investors had provided €6 million in seed capital, following a second-round in 2011 when it secured €4 million. [S5] In October 2008, AirTag launched what it called the first NFC software development kit (SDK). [S6] It included an NFC reader and four types of NFC tags. [S7] In 2012, the company launched another SDK. [S8] This one included hardware for smartphone-based payments. [S9] In 2009, AirTag and its partner Netsize launched *Airtag Pad*, an in-store terminal for clients to check their loyalty points, ask about tailored products, etc. [S10] Reebok hired it for its line of *Go Sport* stores. [S11] Nokia C7, the world's first smartphone with an NFC chip, was able to pick up loyalty points and discount coupons on the phone, through a partnership with AirTag. [S12] AirTag built McDonald's France smartphone app *GoMcDo* which was one of the first to integrate with Apple's Passbook soon after the latter's initial launch with iOS 6 in 2012. [S13] In 2012, Carrefour's mobile app for near-field communication (NFC) purchasing was built by AirTag. [S14] In 2013, French newspaper *L'Express* ranked AirTag among the top 30 French internet startups. [S15] That same spring, AirTag launched KFC’s first mobile wallet to order and pay via smartphone; three months later, 90% of those installing the app were placing orders through it. [S16] Late that year, AirTag admitted it was not profitable. [S17] In 2014, the company had 50 employees when it launched mobile commerce applications for Dia France and for Brioche Dorée. [S18] On November 28, 2018, the sole shareholder IDEMIA Identity et Security France (Courvevoie) decided to dissolve Airtag early without liquidation. [S19] ## Criticism

Whereas AirTag said it launched the first NFC SDK in late 2008, industry magazine *RFID Update* said at the time that there were pre-existing SDK's from Nokia and from Alvin Systems.
qa_pairs.question: In which year did AirTag's KFC mobile wallet see 90% of users placing orders through the app?
